timeline.bodyText: c:geo does not use Serializable put Parcelable. But also the later only if needed. I assume here it is probably not needed at all? (since you use json)
timeline.author: eddiemuc

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: murggel

replies.bodyText:
Hm, I am not sure, if it's needed for storing in DB? But I guess, there only the JSON-String is stored.
On testing on the emulator, I got some leaks-messages, which I have not seen before. I will switch to local master-branch, to check, whether they appear there as well or I have to take a closer look at this. Probably I will need your help then ...
replies.author: murggel

replies.bodyText:
I can assure you that serialization is not needed for db store.
Was this also in the classes before? (In case you moved them) I have the strong feeling it is not needed, but it also doesn't hurt.
replies.author: eddiemuc

replies.bodyText:
It was already in the class before move.
I moved it then for VariableData as well.
replies.author: murggel

timeline.bodyText: I think "getLabel" and "setAutoChar" could be instance methods of class "ButtonData" instead of moving them into the enum. Or am I missing something?
timeline.author: eddiemuc

replies.bodyText:
I just moved the class out of the CalculatorDialog as whole.
But since there are different types of Buttons, (CustomInput, Blank, AutoChar and CustomChar) which leads to different behaviour, this is handled via the abstract methods getLabel and setAutoChar of the enum
replies.author: murggel

timeline.bodyText: +1 for making a separate package out of this! :-)
timeline.author: eddiemuc

timeline.bodyText:
Could org.apache.commons.lang3.CharUtils be used instead?
If not: can this be moved as method to an existing Utils class? Maybe TextUtils?

timeline.bodyText: Is MinDecFormulaParser the only subclass of AbstractLatLonFormulaParser? If yes, why do we need the subclass?
timeline.author: eddiemuc

replies.bodyText: No, there can / should be the others as well, but with your next comment, probably that will be done with reusing the other parser...
replies.author: murggel

timeline.bodyText: There should be coordinate parsers for many coordinates formats in some other class available (alas, they don't parse for variable values inside of course). Can't they be reused somehow (parametereized to accept also letters instead of numbers)?
timeline.author: eddiemuc

replies.bodyText: Nice idea, didn't thougt about that. I will have a look into that...
replies.author: murggel

replies.bodyText:
I looked into it and remembered that I thought about it, but the other parser returns a Point /Double, whereas I need a string. So I just used it to copy and modify.
But I will think, if probably it can be reused somehow else, or just extend the classes with methods returning a string, which then can be converted to double ...
replies.author: murggel

replies.bodyText: If its too complicated don't do it. I assume the formulas only work for MicDec-formatted coordinates anyway, do they?
replies.author: eddiemuc

replies.bodyText:
You are probably right, for the other formats only letters will be accepted instead of digits, but no formula.
Formulas there only can appear in the variables.
But even then it makes probably more sense to reuse some logic...
replies.author: murggel

replies.bodyText:
Did not manage yet to extract the logic.
I will keep the AbstractParser for the other coordinate-formats, if there will be also parsers for it later
replies.author: murggel

timeline.bodyText: Is AbstractLatLonFormulaParser the only subclass of AbstractFormularParser? If yes, why do we need the subclass?
timeline.author: eddiemuc

replies.bodyText: Probably yes,  but with your previous comment, probably that will be done with reusing the other parser...
replies.author: murggel

If I have some more time, I will probably give it another try...

replies.bodyText: Probably yes, but with your previous comment, probably that will be done with reusing the other parser...

replies.author: murggel

timeline.bodyText: This methods performance would profit from "list" being a map (char -> VariableData).  Would that be an adequate data structure for a collection of VariableData's?
timeline.author: eddiemuc

timeline.bodyText: Isn't this the same as calling "getVariable" with "remove=true"?
timeline.author: eddiemuc

replies.bodyText:
Seems so.
I see 3 possibilities:

call getVariable(...false) in the method findAndRemoveData
replace the whole method findAndRemoveData with getVariable(...false)
leave both methods and remove the parameter remove from getVariable and adapt all calls of getVariable(....true)  with findAndRemoveData
combination out of all having 3 functions:


findVariableData without boolean
findVariableDataAndRemove
findVariableData with boolean: the first two calls the third one

I am not sure, which one I prefer, but variant 1 is the less preferred
BTW isn't there any package in java which can handle that?
replies.author: murggel

replies.bodyText: With your next comment, probably variant 3 or 4 will be best
replies.author: murggel

replies.bodyText: I like 3 best :-)
replies.author: eddiemuc

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: murggel

timeline.bodyText: This method modifies the content of parameter "variables", which should not be done. At least there should be a comment on the method telling which params will be modified.
timeline.author: eddiemuc

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: murggel

timeline.bodyText: I dont understand difference between "variables" and "varBank". Maybe a short comment would help?
timeline.author: eddiemuc

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: murggel

timeline.bodyText: If I understand the code correctly, then the value of "variableNames" could be extracted from list "variables". Is this correct? Then this parameter should be removed.

replies.bodyText: I will rename the function and add description
